newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Morocco arrests 67 opposition activists - rights group.
newsitem.headline: Morocco arrests 67 opposition activists - rights group.

text.p: Moroccan police arrested 67 opposition political activists for their campaign to boycott local elections due on June 13, a human rights group said on Saturday.

"A group of 67 militants, members of the opposition Avant-Garde Democratique Socialiste party (PADS), were arrested by police in 10 provinces while campaigning for the boycott of communal elections," a spokesman for the independent Moroccan Human Rights Association said.
Among Morocco's dozen active parties, the PADS was the only opposition group to call for the boycott of local elections.
"Most of the arrested militants will be presented before the court of justice and tried next week," the spokesman said.
Contacted by Reuters, a PADS leader said the arrests aimed at "preventing" the party from expressing its point of view on the elections."
"This is a real terror...a violation of speech freedom and basic principles of human rights," Ahmed Benjelloun, a prominent lawyer and leader of PADS said.
Interior ministry officials were not immediately available for comment.
Campaigning for the elections, which started on May 29, will end on June 12.
More than 102,000 candidates are expected to compete for 24,253 seats in Morocco's local council elections.
A group of 14,447 candidates are standing as independents. The remainder come from 12 political parties.
Local elections are the first of a series which will be capped by a parliamentary poll in September, with a new bicameral parliament being inaugurated by King Hassan on the second Friday of October.
Under the new constitution, the Lower House of parliament will be directly elected through universal suffrage.
Local councils will elect around 80 percent of the members of new Upper House of Parliament being set up under constitutional reforms approved last September.
The new house will have power to vote a no-confidence motion in the government and could topple it.
